question.title: Is there an equivalent to memcpy() in Java?

node.contents: I have a byte[] and would like to copy it into another byte[]. Maybe I am showing my simple 'C' background here, but is there an equivalent to memcpy() on byte arrays in Java?

astNode.text: I have a byte[] and would like to copy it into another byte[]. Maybe I am showing my simple 'C' background here, but is there an equivalent to memcpy() on byte arrays in Java?

node.contents: See also more detail in the accepted answer to http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3208899/how-do-i-clone-a-java-byte-array .

astNode.text: See also more detail in the accepted answer to http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3208899/how-do-i-clone-a-java-byte-array .

node.contents: If you just want an exact copy of a one-dimensional array, use clone().

astNode.text: If you just want an exact copy of a one-dimensional array, use clone().

node.contents: For other array copy operations, use System.arrayCopy/Arrays.copyOf as Tom suggests.

astNode.text: For other array copy operations, use System.arrayCopy/Arrays.copyOf as Tom suggests.

node.contents: In general, clone should be avoided, but this is an exception to the rule.

astNode.text: In general, clone should be avoided, but this is an exception to the rule.

node.contents: +1 for the examples.

astNode.text: +1 for the examples.

node.contents: Use System.arraycopy()

astNode.text: Use System.arraycopy()

node.contents: Example,

astNode.text: Example,

elements.contents: String[] source = { "alpha", "beta", "gamma" }; String[] target = new String[source.length]; System.arraycopy(source, 0, target, 0, source.length);

units.rawText: String[] source = { "alpha", "beta", "gamma"}; String[] target = new String[source.length]; System.arraycopy(source, 0, target, 0, source.length);

node.contents:
or use Arrays.copyOf()
Example,

astNode.text:
or use Arrays.copyOf()
Example,

node.contents:
java.util.Arrays.copyOf(byte[] source, int length) was added in JDK 1.6.

The copyOf() method uses System.arrayCopy() to make a copy of the array, but is more flexible than clone() since you can make copies of parts of an array.

astNode.text:
java.util.Arrays.copyOf(byte[] source, int length) was added in JDK 1.6.

The copyOf() method uses System.arrayCopy() to make a copy of the array, but is more flexible than clone() since you can make copies of parts of an array.

node.contents: I think the second option is more "logical". I never understood why System.arraycopy() is where is, one of the clumsiest possible locations.

astNode.text: I think the second option is more "logical". I never understood why System.arraycopy() is where is, one of the clumsiest possible locations.

node.contents: You might try System.arraycopy or make use of array functions in the Arrays class like java.util.Arrays.copyOf. Both should give you native performance under the hood.

astNode.text: You might try System.arraycopy or make use of array functions in the Arrays class like java.util.Arrays.copyOf. Both should give you native performance under the hood.

node.contents: Arrays.copyOf is probably favourable for readability, but was only introduced in java 1.6.

astNode.text: Arrays.copyOf is probably favourable for readability, but was only introduced in java 1.6.

elements.contents: byte[] src = {1, 2, 3, 4}; byte[] dst = Arrays.copyOf(src, src.length); System.out.println(Arrays.toString(dst));

units.rawText: byte[] src = {1, 2, 3, 4}; byte[] dst = Arrays.copyOf(src, src.length); Systemoutprintln(Arrays.toString(dst));

node.contents: Java actually does have something just like memcpy(). The Unsafe class has a copyMemory() method that is essentially identical to memcpy(). Of course, like memcpy(), it provides no protection from memory overlays, data destruction, etc. It is not clear if it is really a memcpy() or a memmove(). It can be used to copy from actual addresses to actual addresses or from references to references. Note that if references are used, you must provide an offset (or the JVM will die ASAP).

astNode.text: Java actually does have something just like memcpy(). The Unsafe class has a copyMemory() method that is essentially identical to memcpy(). Of course, like memcpy(), it provides no protection from memory overlays, data destruction, etc. It is not clear if it is really a memcpy() or a memmove(). It can be used to copy from actual addresses to actual addresses or from references to references. Note that if references are used, you must provide an offset (or the JVM will die ASAP).

node.contents: Unsafe.copyMemory() works (up to 2 GB per second on my old tired PC). Use at your own risk. Note that the Unsafe class does not exist for all JVM implementations.

astNode.text: Unsafe.copyMemory() works (up to 2 GB per second on my old tired PC). Use at your own risk. Note that the Unsafe class does not exist for all JVM implementations.

node.contents: You can use System.arrayCopy. It copies elements from a source array to a destination array. The Sun implementation uses hand-optimized assembler, so this is fast.

astNode.text: You can use System.arrayCopy. It copies elements from a source array to a destination array. The Sun implementation uses hand-optimized assembler, so this is fast.

node.contents: You can use System.arraycopy
